total_revenue.context: Net sales increased 9% to $149.2 billion in the fourth quarter of 2022, compared with $137.4 billion in Q4 2021. Excluding the $5.0 billion unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates, net sales increased by 12% compared with Q4 2021.
total_revenue.fx_impact: Foreign exchange rates had an unfavorable impact of $5.0 billion on net sales growth.

net_sales.context: North America segment sales increased 13% year-over-year to $93.4 billion in Q4 2022, or increased 14% excluding changes in foreign exchange rates.

operating_expenses.context: Operating expenses for North America increased to $93.603 billion in Q4 2022.

operating_income.context: North America segment operating loss was ($0.2) billion in Q4 2022, compared with operating loss of ($0.2) billion in Q4 2021.

net_sales.context: International segment sales decreased 8% year-over-year to $34.5 billion in Q4 2022, or increased 5% excluding changes in foreign exchange rates.

operating_expenses.context: Operating expenses for International increased to $36.691 billion in Q4 2022.

operating_income.context: International segment operating loss was ($2.228) billion in Q4 2022, compared with operating loss of ($1.6) billion in Q4 2021.

net_sales.context: AWS segment sales increased 20% year-over-year to $21.378 billion in Q4 2022.

operating_expenses.context: Operating expenses for AWS increased to $16.173 billion in Q4 2022.

operating_income.context: AWS segment operating income was $5.205 billion in Q4 2022, compared with $5.3 billion in Q4 2021.

net_sales.context: Consolidated net sales increased to $149.204 billion in Q4 2022, up 9% year-over-year.

operating_expenses.context: Consolidated operating expenses increased to $146.467 billion in Q4 2022, up 19% from Q4 2021.

operating_income.context: Consolidated operating income decreased to $2.737 billion in Q4 2022, compared with $3.5 billion in Q4 2021.

total_expenses.context: Consolidated operating expenses for Q4 2022 were $146.467 billion, up 19% from Q4 2021.
key_factors: Investments in fulfillment and transportation infrastructure
Expanded marketing and general administrative expenses

COGS.context: Cost of goods sold increased to $208 million in Q4 2022.

Fulfillment.context: Fulfillment expenses increased to $757 million in Q4 2022.

Technology_and_content.context: Technology and content expenses increased to $3.126 billion in Q4 2022.

Marketing.context: Marketing expenses increased to $1.092 billion in Q4 2022.

General_and_administrative.context: General and administrative expenses increased to $0.423 billion in Q4 2022.

Other.context: Worldwide shipping costs increased to $24.714 billion in Q4 2022.

Stock_based_Compensation.context: Total stock-based compensation expense increased to $5.606 billion in Q4 2022.

operating_income.context: Consolidated operating income decreased to $2.737 billion in Q4 2022, compared with $3.5 billion in Q4 2021.

net_income.context: Net income was $0.3 billion in Q4 2022, compared with $14.3 billion in Q4 2021.

eps.context: Net income of $0.3 billion translates to $0.03 per diluted share in Q4 2022, compared with $1.39 per diluted share in Q4 2021.

free_cash_flow.context: Free cash flow decreased to an outflow of $11.6 billion for the trailing twelve months, compared with an outflow of $9.1 billion for the trailing twelve months ended December 31, 2021.

operating_cash_flow.context: Operating cash flow increased 1% to $46.8 billion for the trailing twelve months, compared with $46.3 billion for the trailing twelve months ended December 31, 2021.

free_cash_flow_less_principal_repayments.context: Free cash flow less principal repayments of finance leases and financing obligations increased to an outflow of $19.8 billion for the trailing twelve months, compared with an outflow of $20.4 billion for the trailing twelve months ended December 31, 2021.

free_cash_flow_less_equipment_and_other_.context: Free cash flow less equipment finance leases and principal repayments of all other finance leases and financing obligations increased to an outflow of $12.8 billion for the trailing twelve months, compared with an outflow of $14.3 billion for the trailing twelve months ended December 31, 2021.

share_repurchase.context: Share repurchase details not provided in the Q4 2022 financial results.

monthly_active_users.context: No specific user metrics provided in the Q4 2022 financial results.

total_employees.context: Employees (full-time and part-time; excludes contractors & temporary personnel) decreased to 1,541,000 in Q4 2022, down 4% year-over-year.

market_position.description: Amazon continues to lead in various sectors including e-commerce, cloud computing, digital streaming, and innovative technologies.
initiatives: Had a record-breaking holiday season with customers purchasing nearly half a billion items from small businesses in the U.S.

Made Same-Day Delivery even faster in major metropolitan areas in the U.S., such as Los Angeles, San Francisco, Phoenix, Sacramento, and Portland, Oregon, where customers can now receive hundreds of thousands of items within hours.
Attracted more than 100 million viewers worldwide to the first season of The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power, making it the most watched Amazon Original series in every region of the world.
Finished the Thursday Night Football (TNF) season with the youngest median age of any NFL broadcast package since 2013 and viewership up 11% from last season among hard-to-reach 18- to 34-year-olds.
Premiered several Original series and films, including The English, Dr. Seuss Baking Challenge, My Policeman, and Good Night Oppy.
Brought HBO back to Prime Video Channels in the U.S., after reaching an agreement with Warner Bros. Discovery.
Announced new commitments and migrations from AWS customers.
NASDAQ completed the migration of its MRX core trading system to the cloud, delivering a 10% performance improvement for market participants.
NFL and AWS announced the NFL Contact Detection Challenge, inviting experts to use machine learning (ML) and computer vision to predict and prevent injuries.
Yahoo Ad Tech selected AWS as its preferred cloud provider to develop tailored and immersive solutions for brands.
Stability AI selected AWS as its preferred cloud provider to build and train artificial intelligence (AI) models for the best performance at the lowest cost.
Descartes Labs is going all-in on AWS to give customers timely, actionable insights to tackle challenges like enhancing food security and mitigating climate change.
Brookfield Asset Management selected AWS as a preferred cloud provider to advance renewable energy use globally.
Duke Energy is working with AWS on smart grid solutions to improve reliability and resiliency in preparation for rapid electric vehicle adoption.
Wallbox migrated to AWS, enabling customers to return excess energy to the grid and reducing the company’s IT costs by 70%.
American Family Insurance named AWS as its preferred cloud provider to unlock personalized service and security for its 13.1 million policyholders.
Launched AWS Regions in Spain and Switzerland as well as a second Region in India to continue expanding AWS’s infrastructure footprint.
Expanded the AWS Partner Network to help customers accelerate innovation in their organizations and speed their journey to the cloud.
Professional services company Accenture launched a platform that helps customers drive business outcomes up to 50% faster on AWS.

Atos, a provider of managed infrastructure services, will collaborate with AWS to enable customers with large-scale infrastructure outsourcing contracts to accelerate digital transformation and workload migrations to the cloud.
Global business and technology consulting company Slalom will develop vertical solutions and accelerators on AWS for joint customers.
goals: Maintain leadership in e-commerce and cloud services
Expand technological innovations in AI, automation, and autonomous delivery systems
Enhance customer satisfaction and service offerings
Support small and medium-sized businesses
Drive innovation in health and wellness through Amazon Pharmacy and Halo
Strengthen international market presence
Enhance brand protection and anti-counterfeiting efforts
examples: Had a record-breaking holiday season with nearly half a billion items purchased from small businesses in the U.S.
Same-Day Delivery enhancements in major metropolitan areas and availability in Belgium.
Attracted over 100 million viewers to The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.
Finished TNF season with youngest median age and increased viewership among 18-34 year-olds.
Premiered new Original series and films like The English and Good Night Oppy.
Brought HBO back to Prime Video Channels.
Migration of NASAD MRX core trading system to the cloud.
NFL Contact Detection Challenge.
Preferred cloud provider selections by Yahoo Ad Tech, Stability AI, etc.
AWS infrastructure expansions in Spain, Switzerland, and India.
AWS Partner Network expansions with Accenture, Atos, Slalom.

leadership_transition.description: Jeff Bezos, Amazon founder and former CEO, transitioned to the role of Executive Chair in Q3 2021, and Andy Jassy became Chief Executive Officer at that time.
leadership_transition.context: Jeff Bezos stepped down to focus on long-term strategic initiatives and innovation, while Andy Jassy, head of AWS, took over as CEO to lead Amazon's continued growth.
